top_comment.text:
So.. if Schizophrenia is passed on genetically..  If (theoretically) the 
human race prevented people with Schizophrenia from having children, would 
that at least largely eliminate the disorder from future generations?  
Could the same be done with other genetic diseases?

From an ethical point of view, I don't see that it would be wrong, either.  
Not having children isn't a bad thing, and not being allowed to have 
children may not be pleasant, but the other option is to do nothing, and 
allow the conception of individuals who will inevitably suffer.  Should we 
not start being more concerned with future generations, and less on 
ourselves?  Besides, if a person who has Schizophrenia (for example) wanted 
a child, they could adopt one.﻿

comments.text:
+Phazaar
You're right.  Of course ethically speaking and given the lack of knowledge 
we have, we'd have no way to be sure it would work, and therefore it would 
be unethical.  The main idea was the question of if it could possibly 
work.  Other comments have explained that no, it probably wouldn't, because 
it's a mixture of genetic traits that cause it.  I can understand that, and 
thus would never suggest actually carrying out the eugenics practice I 
described.

I would agree that forced sterilization would be unethical as well, even if 
we did know everything about genetics that we needed to.  It's no more 
ethical than involuntary slavery.  But one argument that I keep hearing 
from people is that "it's unfair to the people who wouldn't be born" and 
variations on that.  To which I would have to respond "No more so than a 
condom"

On the other hand though, if I had a condition that had a significantly 
high chance of being passed on genetically, and was detrimental to my 
health/life/well-being, I think I would voluntarily choose not to have 
children.  If I was fit mentally and personally, (eg, not prone to 
depression, violence, etc.) I would probably adopt a child if I wanted 
one.  I might do that anyway...
comments.author: TheOtherGuys2

comments.text:
+TheOtherGuys2 This fails on exactly what eugenics has always (and will 
always) failed on. We do not have anywhere near the necessary scientific 
knowledge to act upon it. We do not know which genes are responsible, we do 
not know which genes are not, we cannot diagnose people who are only 
carriers, and thus the exercise is redundant; yes, instance of a particular 
disorder may decrease slightly, but it's very fair to say that without the 
requisite knowledge we would be putting countless people through entirely 
undue and unimaginable suffering to alleviate only the potential suffering 
of future generations. You're only dealing in likelihoods after all; two 
schizophrenic parents do not necessitate schizophrenic children. 

As a secondary reason that eugenics is absurd, it narrows the field of 
human mutation, which is simultaneously guaranteed to narrow our chances of 
survival versus new illnesses (and current ones), changes in environment 
etc. We know, for example, that sickle cell anaemia functions as a strong 
resistor (not cure nor preventative, but resistance nevertheless) to 
HIV/AIDS. If there were a similar illness in our future (which likelihood 
is, there is) that began to eradicate the human population, it's only due 
to seemingly negative traits that life may be able to persist beyond such 
an epidemic. We do not know/have the ability to research what it is about 
those of us who are left now that made us resistant to the Plague, as it 
rather efficiently killed all of us without whatever genetic mutation that 
was. It could be that people without that genetic mutation had an almost 0% 
rate of depression, or anxiety, or suicidal thoughts. If we had attempted 
to sterilise (literally or through governmental mandate) those of our 
ancestors who suffered from depression, humanity could have been wiped out. 
Both are only theoretical suppositions, but it ought to be obvious that 
within the infinite expanse of time and space, these situations most likely 
will arise. If our ethics dictate that the survival of the human race is 
even equal in importance with the judicial use of public money, it's our 
ethical responsibility to ensure mutation is accepted, tolerated, and 
supported. 

But since I think the point here is much more significantly ethical than it 
is scientific, let's look at the actual ethical conundrum. Suppose these 
things were not factors. In a world where we had absolute knowledge of 
exactly which genes caused Schizophrenia, divine wisdom that these 
mutations would never in any way prove beneficial for humanity, and where 
foetal screening was unnecessary as we could guarantee that a person would 
have a schizophrenic child if they bred, should we allow them to breed? 

The answer's a resounding, 'YES!' isn't it? At what point did we gain the 
authority to take the most natural action we can perform in our lifetimes 
and start classifying who was and who was not worthy of this? At what point 
did we become knowledgeable and wise enough to deem a life lived with 
Schizophrenia a life so unpleasant as to be not worth living? I have plenty 
of friends with Schizophrenia who would spit on you for the suggestion. 
Would we also be applying this profound wisdom to whether or not couples 
should be allowed to breed based upon other factors, like health, 
education, lifestyle etc? The great human success story is always fraught 
with illness. So many brilliant people only ever came to their brilliant 
conclusions courtesy of the disabilities and illnesses they have suffered. 
Would their contributions to humanity have come from another source if not 
from them? Perhaps, but we've no evidence to support the idea that they 
would. 

And in final conclusion, if you still don't get it, and you still think 
there's a rationale for massively increasing the amount of human suffering 
in the world (because I'm fairly certain as a person who does suffer mental 
health issues, my suffering is balanced by the rest of the things in my 
life... The suffering of those couples who discover they can't have 
children of their own, is not... And one of the main things that does 
balance out those lows in my life is the high that (if I am so fortunate) 
will be having children...) just remember: we do not have that perfect 
situation described above... We will not EVER have that knowledge, that 
wisdom, that guarantee. We'll always be under-informed, scrabbling around 
in the dark hoping our guesses will make some positive change. Why not 
devote our guesses to things with a much higher chance of success, or 
things without the guarantee of collateral damage?

comments.text:
It's almost never as easy and straightforward as a single gene causing a 
psychological disorder. What has been found in schizophrenia for example is 
that they have no specific genes that differs from average. But they often 
have different numbers of the same genes. So say you might have three 
copies of gene x in your dna while a schizophrenic might have 5 copies of 
the same stretch of dna. But still there is no genetic predestination for 
schizophrenia. Deviating from the normal distribution of extra copies of 
the same genes makes you more likely to develop the condition but it 
doesn't automatically doom you with schizophrenia nor does "normal" genes 
guarantee that you won't develop schizophrenia. It's a messy and insanely 
complicated interaction of genes, fetal development and then life 
experience that determines wether you get schizophrenia or not. In short we 
haven't yet a clue wether your proposed eugenics program would be efficient 
enough to merit it's implementation. Especially as a better understanding 
of the development and gene-enviroment interactions could lead to say a 
simple pill for pregnant mothers or a preventantive psychological therapy 
for kids with high risks of developing the disease.
comments.author: Skadu Skitai

top_comment.text:
Re: Sherlock calling himself a "high-functioning sociopath"--Steven Moffat 
himself said it's total nonsense:

“He always is [bullshitting]. He doesn’t think that at all. He doesn’t 
think any of those things, but he wants to think that he does, just as he 
wants to think he’s a high-functioning sociopath. He’s not a sociopath, nor 
is he high-functioning. He’d really like to be a sociopath. But he’s so 
f*cking not. The wonderful drama of Sherlock Holmes is that he’s aspiring 
to this extraordinary standard. He is at root an absolutely ordinary man 
with a very, very big brain. He’s repressed his emotions, his passions, his 
desires, in order to make his brain work better — in itself, a very 
emotional decision, and it does suggest that he must be very emotional if 
he thinks emotions get in the way. I just think Sherlock Holmes must be 
bursting!”

Source: "Sherlock’s Best Man Speech is Basically Fanfic, Moffat Says He’s 
Absolutely Not A Sociopath", on the Tor website. (I'd put in a link but it 
won't post, but a search on the article title should pinpoint the article 
for you.)﻿
top_comment.author: Rachel Reiss

comments.text:
+Tabby Cat The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM 
IV-TR) is another widely used tool for the diagnosis and it defines 
sociopath traits as:

A) Pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others 
occurring since age 15 years, as indicated by three or more of the 
following:

Failure to conform to social norms with respect to lawful behaviors as 
indicated by repeatedly performing acts that are grounds for arrest-- 
Check, I believe

Deception, as indicated by repeatedly lying, use of aliases, or conning

Impulsiveness or failure to plan ahead- This one no

Irritability and aggressiveness-- Check, he's irritable a lot 

Reckless disregard for safety of self or others
Consistent irresponsibility, as indicated by repeated failure to sustain

Lack of remorse as indicated by being indifferent to or rationalizing

Callous unconcern for the feelings of others.-- I'm not sure about this one

Markedly prone to blame others or to offer plausible rationalization for

comments.text:
A Sociopath is someone who finds it very hard, if not impossible, to have 
any sort of empathetic response occur naturally. Often they can generate 
empathy towards something if they know it is expected within that context, 
but that is not the case for everyone; And some simply choose not to.

What would have been (likely one of several things) called 
"High-Functioning" Sociopathy back when Sir Arthur Conan Doyle was alive is 
usually better diagnosed as Asperger's Syndrome today; Wherein one of the 
main components is the extreme difficulty for the brain to recognise 
inflection within body-language and voice, causing the person to take 
things like sarcasm and wry jokes seriously, often to offence.

This estrangement from what makes up a significant portion of inter-human 
communication also makes it harder to see things things from someone else's 
perspective, leading to an apparent lack of empathy.

-A Modern Sociopath

remembered. Think "Momento," not "All My children."

comments.text:
It sounds to me like she may have what my mother has, which is 
Schizoaffective Disorder, which is essentially a combination of 
schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schizoaffective_disorder. Different states 
have different laws regarding guardianship and getting someone the help 
they need even if its against their will. I recommend contacting your local 
government and asking. My mother is normal and sweet 99% of the time but 
sometimes she builds up immunities to her medicine and has to be 
hospitalized until it's re-adjusted back to normal levels. Hopefully if 
you're able to find a law to get your mother help , she'll realize you were 
just helping and won't hold anything against you. My mother always 
understands. I hate it also because she remembers everything she says and 
does against her control once she has control back and feels guilty for it. 
My best advice is to be as loving as supporting as you can, even when you 
feel frustrated with the situation. Remember, it's nothing that she can 
control.I hope I've helped!

There is one OCD about washing your hand and being very afraid of germs.

There have been instances where people have been washing their hands so 
much that the skin peeled off and serious injuries to their hands have been 
created.

avoid any human or non human animal contact and are afraid of basic tasks.

study or anything frankly.

inconveniences for these people related to stress or some kind of brain 
dysfunction.

top_comment.text:
I'm right there with you until that tiny bit about 'psychopathy' being an 
outdated term- it is most certainly not an outdated term, at least, not in 
the forensic arena, and professionals use all three (Psychopathy, 
Sociopathy, and ASPD) interchangeably. Lately, more often than not, 
professionals ascribe to the thought that a psychopath is 'born' while a 
sociopath/ASPD person is 'made' and ties this all rather closely to the 
nature v. nurture debate. Terms are not exactly officially defined like the 
DSM has done in the past, and psychopathy/sociopathy is not technically a 
diagnosis, but they are all still constructs that are heavily researched in 
forensic populations and there is talk of bringing them back as part of a 
"spectrum" classification to ASPD. There's also some really cool theories 
on evolution and how that ties in to psychopathy. The rest is spot on and 
THANK YOU for this video. ﻿

comments.text:
Hello Courtney
My father suffers from "paranoid schizophrenia" (schizophrenia with 
paranoia). I did not grow up with him (unlike you, I guess) and can 
therefore not say what living with someone with that condition might feels 
like. I never smoked weed or did any other drugs. I rarely drank alcohol, 
almost alway very moderately, way below average. I just did not feel the 
urge to try drugs or get drunk. I found it stupid. At age 20 or 21 I 
realized that not smoking weed (the most common and socially accepted drug 
where I live) was a very good idea in retrospect. Because smoking weed can 
lead to schizophrenia. Or to put it more exactly: If you have the 
predisposition, it can lead to an outbreak of schizophrenia. So I decided 
to never do drugs, just to be as safe as possible. For about eight years, I 
did not know more than that. I don't know why I did not do some research. 
Because in these years in my mind I had this more or less fifty percent 
chance of having inherited the disposition from my father. Today I know 
that there is only a probability of about 10 to 15 or 10 to 20% to inherit 
the disposition if only a one of your parents (biological father or mother) 
has schizophrenia. That was quite a relief. Also I found out that things 
like too much stress can cause schizophrenia if you have the genetic 
disposition. So I try to take care of myself stress-wise and just stick 
with not taking any drugs. My advice to you is to do some research, some 
calculating, not do drugs, try to avoid stress and always have in mind 
(somewhere far in the back, otherwise it might easily cause unnecessary 
worries and - in your case - "dangerous" stress) that you have these 
diseases in your family. Also take care with anti-psychotic drugs 
(anti-depressants, tranquilizers etc.) and inform your doctor about your 
family member's conditions, even if you are not directly asked about them.
comments.author: Marie Lastname

That would be preferrable of course, but I can't really see that happening. 
These conditions are relatively rare and people suffering from them are 
usually simply unable to fit into society at all.

Pretty much everyone on this planet knows or knew a cancer patient. Learned 
from them or their friends and family about cancer. We know how cancer 
works and kills and how it can render a person a physical wreck with the 
chemo / radiation treatments and frequent operations. Because we (or those 
close to us) had friends or family that suffered from it.

But those social disorders? You don't meet them, you don't interact with

comments.text:
+Andy Anderson  "Whether we use them carelessly or not does nothing to the 
overall scheme of things."
Nope. If these things get rooted in the general mind as trivial, neglegible 
things you'll make it much harder on people who actually suffer from these 
conditions.

E.g. aspergers. Many tv shows, movies and novels have some kind of 
half-genius aspergers guy... people now expect those diagnosed with 
aspergers to be some sort of half genius *all the time*. Leading to a "oh, 
that's not so bad, you may have poor social skills but are awesome at 
math!" when that's really not the case.
Or depression. Usually portraied as moody, broody, mysterious types... who 
can overcome their sadness through friendship! When in reality it ends in 
the person killing themselves after decades of lethargy and unhappiness. 
Those suffering from depression already hear a "c'mon, just cheer up! Just 
be happy, it's not hard!" every day from family, friends and others around 
them... even though they just fucking can't. And every "cheer up" ends up 
being just another stab at your self conscience, making you wonder why you 
can't be normal, after all everyone tells you it's so easy.
Or OCD. The neat freaks, tidy, always on time, a few funny ticks.... Yeah. 
Good luck holding on to any job when you have to go wash your hands 30 
times an hour and being absolutely helpless to change that. Good luck 
finding a girl/boyfriend that keeps up with all your ticks, and a circle of 
friends that understands that you cannot come to the movies because you 
keep messing up the house-leaving ritual and so cannot leave the house.

Yes, if you're only talking in a small circle of friends with one person 
afflicted with "whatever-disorder" it doesn't matter much, that person will 
probably understand. But on the large scale? You're making life even more 
unbearable for those that suffer from these conditions.
comments.author: Tim Flint

top_comment.text:
I always understood Sociopathy as the less harmful Psychopathy.

Let me explain.

You are a sociopath if you simply don't care about the people around you. 
If your actions cause harm you don't really care. You might fake it, 
knowing logically that it is bad based on what you've learned. But on a 
true emotional level you don't care at all.

Psychopathy is the condition in which causing harm is granting your 
pleasure. You basically enjoy causing suffering to those around you.

While a sociopath can be harmful to society, he can at least function on a 
logical level, and might never actually cause harm to anyone.
But a psychopath is actively looking for ways where he or she can ruin the 
lives of others for their own personal gain, be it materialistic or simply 
on an emotional level.

For example children who torture animals when they are little have clear 
psychopathic behavior tendencies. A child who simply doesn't care about 
their dog, or cat or rabbit dying are merely sociopaths.

I could be totally wrong on this here, maybe all of it is psychopathy but 
you have different gradients of intensity.
But at least this is how I always understood it.﻿
top_comment.author: Quiestre

comments.text:
Heyyo, 
Totally normal way to look at it. In fact, that's probably how most people 
understand it.That understanding comes from the fact that "psychopath" is a 
term that was made up by the media many years ago, and it kind of... well, 
stuck. At the time, sociopath was the real medical term. So the 
understanding you describe came about. The thing to keep in mind is that 
"Sociopath" is itself an outdated term. It's not even included in the 
current DSM (the diagnostic book for psychology). Sociopathy is now 
understood to be much more complicated and can refer to various personality 
disorders. You can keep looking at it your way, it's just a little bit too 
general for some people's liking.
comments.author: Joseph Auringer

comments.text:

I want to say that I have always understood it like the way you described. 
In my understanding, there is a difference between sociopath and

The 1st path is killing for the sake of killing/pleasure. These people have

top_comment.text:
Honestly, I have OCD, and I don't care when people use it as a term. I 
don't like it when people use it only to describe someone who is a 
clean-freak, though, since OCD can come in many different "flavors". For 
example, my OCD comes to food (and other things, but mainly food). I don't 
like people even sneezing around me when I'm eating, and when they do, I'll 
not only freak out on the inside, but I'll often times stop eating for the 
rest of the day. The sneezing thing is mostly gone, but even just someone 
touching my plate/cup, etc. will make me not eat... for the rest of the 
day. Honestly, it sucks, and I really wish I could get rid of it 
altogether, and my medicine really doesn't help. It used to suck more when 
I was a little kid, because I used to go to birthday parties and not eat 
the cake... I wouldn't even eat my own cake. My OCD also is bad, because it 
makes me a very picky eater. I only have a variety of three to four foods 
in my diet, and most I'll rarely change it. Worse more, it has to be cooked 
a specific style, look a certain way, and taste exactly the same as it 
always has. Otherwise, I just won't eat it. I remember camping once, and I 
flat out didn't eat for most of the weekend, because I threw up at the 
thought of eating something not regular to me. 

Probably worse than everything listed above, I have had asthma my entire 
life. I've used inhalers since the fourth grade to stop from, you know, 
having an asthma attack. However, my OCD for food and things like that kind 
of went the same for my inhalers. This meant that if someone as even 
touched the inhaler, I wouldn't use it and we had to call in a new one. ﻿

comments.author: batman88891

comments.text:
+batman88891 I have OCD too, the thing that helped the most was just 
forcing myself to ignore what my brain was telling me. For me it was just 
refusing to flick the light switch or count my fingers, it may be harder 
for you because you'll have to force yourself to do something, which is 
harder than forcing yourself to do nothing. You really have to trust that 
what your mind is telling you is wrong, and that everything will be fine if 
you don't listen to it. It's like trying to come off from an addiction, 
there will be 'withdrawal symptoms' as you'd expect with OCD, but my 
compulsions are extremely reduced now, i only have very minor ones on 
occasion. 

On occasion I'll still suffer badly from intrusive thoughts, but they're 
slowly becoming less frequent. It's now also a large part of my personality 
that i wont do anything without knowing why I'm doing it. That's a positive 
though, I can easily identify if I'm becoming addicted to something, and it 
gives me more insight into the workings of anything I'm doing.

comments.text:
Autism is a strange thing to classify because the people who make decisions 
constantly change their minds. Right now, it's a spectrum disorder, with 
each person with autism somewhere on the spectrum based on how much it 
affects them. In the simplest terms, it is a strange wiring of the brain 
compared to how it usually is. In more complicated terms: motor skills, 
social skills, verbal skills, etc may be weaknesses balanced with an 
unusually high aptitude in a narrow field (and sometimes more than one 
field). STEM fields are the most common, but arts, history, and geography 
are also common fields. People like Thomas Jefferson, Albert Einstein, Mark 
Twain, Thomas Edison, and many other American heroes are believed to have 
autism (but we will never really know for sure), but today we have 
successful people with autism in our modern world, like Bill Gates. Given 
this, and the fact that I couldn't care less about politically correct 
crap, I'd say that autism is both a disability and an "antidisability". 
Take this from someone who has been surrounded by kids with autism and 
living with it for 16 years.

captions.text:
At some point, you’ve probably heard someone
call their emotional ex-boyfriend a psycho.

Or maybe they said that their tidy roommate
had OCD, or their unpredictable neighbor was

totally schizo, or their moody sister was
bipolar.
We do this a lot...and let’s stop.

Think about it this way...if your friend doesn’t
like sugar, you aren’t like “Ugh, he’s

such a diabetic.” Just imagine saying “Oh!
My ex was a TOTAL cancer patient. He was sick
ALL THE TIME!” Ughh!

Many mental health professionals point out
that using diagnostic terms as misplaced metaphors

for odd behavior, personality traits, or even
changes in the stock market ultimately minimizes

serious conditions, and the people who have
them.

So we’re here today to help clear up some
of these definitions, and explain why the

weather isn’t schizophrenic, and how your
ex probably isn't actually a psychopath.
[Intro]

First off, it’s important to understand
what "psychological disorder" really means
to the experts.

Psychologists define a disorder as a deviant,
distressful, and dysfunctional pattern of

thoughts, feelings, or behavior that interferes
with a person’s ability to function in a
healthy way.

Now, let’s break that down: Deviant doesn’t
mean something like dastardly or raunchy -- it

just means something that’s different from
your general social norm. And that can be

pretty broad; like, serial killers are deviant
from the norm, but so are geniuses and Olympians.

So, to be classified as a disorder, those
deviant thoughts or behavior need to cause

the person, or people around them, actual
distress, which pretty much means a feeling
that something is... off.

And that distress can turn into a harmful
dysfunction if it limits a person’s ability
to live and work.

Take anxiety, for example. It’s something
that we all have to some degree -- getting

the jitters before a first date or a big speech
in front of a crowd - totally normal.

But being so distressed at the thought of
interacting with others that you actually

can't leave your house … then that’s a
disorder.

So, your roommate does not have obsessive
compulsive disorder, or OCD, just because

she can’t bear to have dirty dishes in the
sink. But she very well might if her compulsions

are interfering with her ability to live a
healthy and happy life.

OCD isn’t about being neat, or particular,
or just deciding that you really like the
color orange and want to wear it a lot.

It’s a serious, often debilitating condition
characterized by unwanted repetitive thoughts,

which can be known as obsessions, and when
they’re accompanied by actions, those are
called compulsions.

For people with OCD, compulsive behavior can
be a way to try to relieve the intense anxiety

that comes with obsessive thoughts -- like
a fear that, say, if you don’t walk over

and touch that light switch exactly four times,
something terrible is going to happen.
Kind of puts the dirty dishes in perspective.

And bee tee dubs, if you don’t wanna wash
your dishes and your roommate is mad at you,

that is not their problem, because CLEAN YOUR
DANG DISHES, JEREMY, AND WOULD IT KILL YOU
TO TAKE OUT THE TRASH ONCE A YEAR!

Another term I’m sure you’ve heard -- and
heard used incorrectly -- is “schizophrenic.”

Really not a suitable way to describe your
moody neighbor, just because he called the

cops last week when your music was too loud,
but then came back a few days later with leftover
birthday cake.

That is not being schizophrenic -- that’s
just a person being nice to you one day, and
not nice another.

True schizophrenia is pretty rare -- affecting
only about one percent of the global population

-- and it’s probably the most stigmatized
and misunderstood psychological disorder of
them all.

And that might be why the term is so often
misused. We see the term “schizophrenia”

used in the media all the time, to describe
political flip-flopping and fluctuations in

the stock market, even eccentric celebrity
style choices.

One study of the terms “schizophrenic”
and “schizophrenia” in US media found

that 28 percent of references to the condition
were casual metaphors...usually about someone
or something seeming to have multiple personalities.

And guess what….schizophrenia has nothing
to do AT ALL with having multiple personalities.

This myth may have its origin in the fact
that schizophrenia literally means “split

mind”, because the condition is marked by
thoughts and behavior that are out of sync

with a person’s actual surroundings and
situations. Their mind is split with REALITY...not
with itself.

People suffering from schizophrenia often
suffer from delusions, either of grandeur,

like thinking you’re the Queen of England,
or of extreme paranoia and persecution -- like

thinking the CIA and the mafia - or both - are
out to get you.

People who have schizophrenia are also likely
to suffer from hallucinations -- that is,

to see or hear something that isn’t there,
while lacking the ability to reliably judge
what is and isn’t real.

So, “schizophrenic” is not a synonym for
“inconsistent.” It’s a devastating disease

and one of the leading causes of disability
in the world.

Now, speaking of mood swings -- as well as
things we shouldn’t use to describe superficial

things, let's talk about bipolar. You may
recognize it by its older name -- "manic depression."

But like depression, bipolar is a type of
mood disorder.

Our moods are basically long-term emotional
states that are pretty subjective and hard

to pin down, but they usually fall within
two broad categories with very fancy technical
names -- good and bad.

Mood disorders are marked by emotional extremes
and problems in regulating moods.

So, the symptoms of depressive disorders include
prolonged feelings of hopelessness and lethargy,

while bipolar disorders are typified by alternating
among depressive, manic, and what you might

call more normal or stable phases -- often
between phases multiple times a month, week,
or even a single day.

And keep in mind that mania isn’t about
being super happy, or energetic. A true manic

episode is an intense period of restless and
often overly optimistic hyperactivity, during

which your estimation of yourself and your
ideas and your abilities can often get really
skewed.

A person experiencing a manic episode might
start feeling awesome, but quickly start to

show some seriously poor judgement as they
empty their bank accounts on shopping sprees.

When they come down off that sleepless high,
they often fall, hard, into sometimes suicidal
lows.

Which brings us to our final, and perhaps
most popular psych term, mis-used since the
days of Alfred Hitchcock: Psycho.

Psychopathy is another outdated term -- it’s
more often called sociopathy these days, but

professionals know the condition more technically
as antisocial personality disorder.

It’s probably the most extreme and severe
type of personality disorder, which are some

of the most difficult disorders to diagnose
and, frankly, to live with.

That’s mainly because, unlike most disorders,
people with personality disorders often aren’t

aware of their condition. Sometimes, they
think it’s everyone else who’s got the
problem.

People with antisocial personality disorder
exhibit a lack of conscience, even towards

friends and family members. Their destructive
behavior surfaces in childhood or adolescence,

beginning with excessive lying, fighting,
stealing, violence, or manipulation.

They basically don’t care about any negative
consequences of their actions, and because

they lack the capacity for empathy, they don’t
give a dang about you, or anyone else.

So even though we really love Benedict Cumberbatch,
his Sherlock Holmes was flat-out wrong when
he described himself as a sociopath.

I mean, just look at how he and Watson get
along. It's adorable!

Now, just what causes antisocial disorder
or any of the other disorders I’ve mentioned

is complicated, and honestly we have a long
way to go in understanding it.

Some conditions seem to be pretty clearly
linked to biological factors such as genetics

and brain chemistry, while others seem to
stem from specific situations, or environmental
factors, like stress or trauma.

And some cases appear to have roots in both
causes: People could have a genetic predisposition

to a condition that tends to run in families,
like schizophrenia, but may only have symptoms

if they’re triggered by their surroundings.
If you want to learn more about these disorders

and other scientific aspects of your mind,
you can head over to Crash Course, where we’ve

been studying psychology all year.
But in the end, we’re not here to tell you

how to talk -- or, for that matter, what to
be offended by -- we’re just all about understanding

the world around us, including people. And
it’s probably fair to say that using clinical

diagnoses to describe haircuts or dishwashing
habits only fuels the misunderstanding of
mental illness.

A final note...in general, when talking about
people with medical disorders, try not to

let the disorder define them. Instead of saying
that someone is a schizophrenic, say that

they have schizophrenia. It's hard enough
to try not to become your disease when your

disease is inside your brain; it's even worse
when it's inside everyone else's too.

So next time someone is annoying or alarming
you with their behavior, allow me to suggest
a thesaurus.

Thanks for watching this SciShow Infusion
-- especially to our Subbable subscribers.

To learn how you can support us in exploring
the world, just go to subbable.com.

And as always, don’t forget to go to YouTube.com/scishow
and subscribe!

title: 4 Psychological Terms That You're Using Incorrectly
